problems.author: Doyoon Kim
problems.question: What does the Bohr model say about electrons in certain circular orbits around the nucleus?
options: They emit radiation continuously while orbiting
They move in fixed orbits without radiating energy
They can occupy any orbit of any radius
problems.hint: Bohr introduced the idea of stationary states.
problems.detailed: According to the Bohr model, electrons revolve around the nucleus in fixed circular orbits (stationary states) and do not radiate energy while in those orbits.

problems.author: Doyoon Kim
problems.question: According to Bohr’s postulates, when does an electron emit a photon?
options: When it stays in the same orbit
Only when it spirals into the nucleus
When it jumps from a higher energy orbit to a lower one
problems.hint: Photon emission happens during electron transitions.
problems.detailed: When an electron moves from a higher energy level (n₂) to a lower one (n₁), a photon is emitted with energy equal to the difference between these orbits: \(h\nu = E_{n_2} - E_{n_1}\).

problems.author: Doyoon Kim
problems.question: What is quantized in Bohr’s model related to electrons orbiting the nucleus?
problems.hint: One of Bohr’s postulates quantizes some property of the electron motion.
problems.detailed: Bohr’s model postulates that the angular momentum of an electron is quantized: \(L = n\hbar = n\left(\frac{h}{2\pi}\right)\), where n is a positive integer.

problems.author: Doyoon Kim
problems.question: What is a limitation of the Bohr model?
options: It correctly predicts spectra for multi-electron atoms
It explains the uncertainty in electron position
It only works accurately for hydrogen or hydrogen-like (one electron) atoms
It describes electrons orbiting in elliptical orbits
problems.hint: It fails for atoms more complex than hydrogen.
problems.detailed: The Bohr model only works accurately for hydrogen and hydrogen-like atoms with one electron. It fails to explain spectra of multi-electron atoms and doesn’t incorporate the wave nature of electrons or quantum mechanics fully.
